pillars.title: A closed loop: Mind × Market × Price Action
pillars.lead: Strategies are an expression. The ceiling is defined by how you read the market, execute rules, and stay consistent under stress.

mind.title: Mind
mind.def: Remove emotion from the decision chain and return execution to rules.
mind.p1: Identify triggers: impulsive entries, revenge trades, overtrading
mind.p2: Build guardrails: pre-trade checks and hard limits
mind.p3: Review behavior: post-loss patterns and corrective actions

market.title: Market
market.def: Read price through structure and narrative—not signals.
market.p1: Recognize regimes: trend, range, transition, participant shifts
market.p2: Build a framework: narrative, liquidity, and key locations
market.p3: Make it reusable: a consistent breakdown template

price.title: Price Action
price.def: Read force and location: where it pushes, where it fails, how it falsifies.
price.p1: Force: the quality of impulse and pullback
price.p2: Location: structural pivots and risk boundaries
price.p3: Falsification: failure patterns and exit rules

path.title: From ideas to process: five steps to an operating system
path.lead: Each step includes actions, deliverables, and evaluation criteria—so learning turns into repeatable execution.

s1.title: Perception (Market)
s1.do: Run one structured breakdown each week: narrative, regime, key locations.
s1.metric: Can you explain different markets with one framework?

s2.title: Discipline (Mind)
s2.do: Remove impulse via pre-trade checks and hard limits.
s2.metric: Do rule violations trend down over time?

s3.title: Structure (Price Action)
s3.do: Use an SOP to judge push/failure and define falsification points.

s4.title: Execution (SOP)
s4.do: Write risk parameters into rules and log every decision.

s5.title: Review (Iteration)
s5.do: Publish a weekly review: evidence, error types, corrective actions.
s5.metric: Does recurrence of the same errors decline?

faq.title: Questions
faq.lead: Define boundaries first. Training only works with clear constraints.

q1.a: No. Trading involves significant risk and any return promise is not credible. The goal here is a trainable, auditable process: a framework, disciplined execution, and a review loop.

q2.a: If you’re willing to log, review, and train consistency. You don’t need to be perfect—you need to be honest about your patterns.

q3.a: If you only want entry/exit signals, refuse to log and review, or treat trading as emotional release.

q4.q: How much time does it take?
q4.a: A weekly breakdown, a weekly written review, and daily execution logging. The cadence adapts to your schedule and frequency.

q5.a: Framework (Market) and discipline (Mind) first, then structured reading (Price Action), then formalize rules into an SOP and iterate through reviews.

q6.a: We work from your logs and reviews: identify error types, set guardrails, formalize parameters, and output your SOP plus a baseline scorecard.

q7.a: Skill is not the first bottleneck. The starting point is logging and review. Consistency comes from training, not talent.

q8.a: No. This site is for education and discussion only. Nothing here is investment advice.

q9.a: No. The work is framework and discipline: define a rationale, define falsification, and review execution. Signals don’t build repeatability.

q10.a: You’ll find it in the footer and the Terms page. Confirm your risk tolerance and plan risk before trading.
